title: Pre-trip routing application

author: Silke Forkert, PTV Planung Transport Verkehr AG

segmentation: I hope you enjoyed the presentations given so far and I will now start with the pre trip routing application.
After all these more technical presentations I tried to keep my presentation little bit more what we can do in the end with the heavy root.
Project, so let's begin.
It's a little bit of the more stuff here.
I'm a cable so.
I hope you can hear everything.
So the contribution of PTV in the project we were involved in three work packages.
And there are three different departments.
FT TV who worked in the work packages with the aggregation of formats.
And sources of available dynamic data.
Then we were involved in world cricket.
Three.

This was the development of the pre trip routing application supporting track profile and specific route calculation and invite packet forwarded the vism simulation of track rooting for the South of Sweden and for this part I can introduce my colleague Thomas Bears in the 2nd row is responsible for this work packet.
So let's get it over.

Through the pre trip route application, the aim of the routing application was to provide the user the best alternative route for a heavy goods vehicle based on additional para meters like fuel consumption, CO2 emissions, effects on the infrastructure and Traffic Safety and driver comfort.
On the picture you can see what happens if the truck driver doesn't use our good routing in the end.
Just a small picture.
So what has been done in the last three years?
First of all, we defined our so called heavy Rd modes.
And this was to give.
Something is with hello.
Can you hear me?
It's OK. To give the user the possibility to choose in the end either the lowest fuel consumption route or the most Traffic Safety route, or the most driver comfort Rd.
And in the second step we integrated the additional track attributes case already introduced as part of the project in an uptake Sweden map.
And in the third step we defined the defined product, use cases were implemented.
And they are a the routing a heavy goods vehicle based on a specific track profile and selected mode be obtaining 5 allowable routes.
See obtaining the recommended route out of the five allowable routes and inadi step the navigation of the driver according to the chosen recommended route.
So in this slide I.
Put the track attributes which were included in the Sweden map.
As you can see, we have additional physical restrictions, hazardous materials, restrictions, legal restrictions, and the warning information.
So.
To receive a root, the user can select one of the predefined vehicle profiles.
And we have predefined 3 vehicle types.
With different crosswaite and number of axles.
And if the user have another truck that we can't find the data in the predefined, he can also create his own vehicle profile.
Depending on the actual car or vehicle.
And here you can see this is the routing application.
This surface and here the user can fill in the special track profile data.
So in the next step, the user can choose also the following additional vehicle information and.
Something strong with the microphone getting loud and OK.
He can Additionally select one of the mission classes of the used trucks.
We predefined Ruban to uniform.
He can also select out of the actual load class of the vehicle if the class is empty or partially loaded or full, and he can also choose if the vehicle has any noise reduction equipment on board.
Then to start rude requests we need surely the starting and end point.
We need the starting date and we will.
We need the heavy Rd mode for the calculation of the recommended route.
So this is what it looked like.
User interface.
To obtain the five allowable routes, routing is done into taking into account all relevant para meters.
As already mentioned, the additional track attributes the vehicle data and the selected mode.
And you can see over there this is the address where the user can put in where he wants to start, and for our test route we used.
Sorry for perhaps the wrong prolongation.
It's from Opus two young thing I think, and it is better in Sweden and on this side you have the map with already the five routes that the calculation has in the end of their results.
So they are marked in different colors as you can see is 12345.
So.
And then you have the five allowable routes.
They are displayed with all relevant costs.
You can see this here.
It's 125 with also the map and there you have the total distance.
The total time I think fuel consumption, noise and then you can.
It was just an example which.
Parramatta so user wants to have in the end.
The user of the system can choose now one of the routes depending on his desired mode.
And the children can be handed over via an interface to the track navigation system of PT, and it looks like that.
OK. To give you a short image of what this truck navigation system looks like, I prepared a little simulation and you can see on the left side.
Side you can see in a short distance that the routing is made for a normal passenger car or normal non standardized routing and on the right side there will be a specific track navigation routing.
So I started.

So here you can see the car can follow the street and there there's forbidden for the trucks, though it has to go over there and this image is shown for the truck driver via the onboard unit in the car.
OK, that's it.
Very short.
And the results of the pre trip routing application were tested in Sweden.
We had a Volvo truck and we had a viable test driver and you can see the equipment for logging the data.
We took four runs on the test and routes and we locked all data per route and for each of the four runs.
And the whole few tests were documented in terms of protocols, deliverables and pictures.
And if you like to want to have more information about the tests, and I think we will have another presentation from Anita and the deliverables can be downloaded on the web page.
Thank you.
